qas.question: What type of conduct of a party to a treaty can invalidate the consent of another party?
What type of action, either direct or indirect, of a state's representative by another type of party to a treaty can invalidate a state's consent?
Coercion of a representative or a state itself will result in what happening to its consent to a treaty?
Coercion of a state or its what through the threat or use of force, if used to obtain the consent of that state to a treaty, will invalidate that consent?
What must  be true of coercion through the threat or use of force of a party to treaty for it to invalidate the state's consent to a treaty?

answers.text: used to obtain the consent of that state to a treaty

context: Consent will also be invalidated if it was induced by the <a0_0>fraudulent conduct<a0_0/> of another party, or by the direct or indirect "<a1_0>corruption<a1_0/>" of its representative by another party to the treaty. Coercion of either a <a3_0>representative<a3_0/>, or the state itself through the threat or use of force, if <a4_0>used to obtain the consent of that state to a treaty<a4_0/>, will <a2_0>invalidate that consent<a2_0/>.
